Vulnerability.Title: irqbalance bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The irqbalance packages provide a daemon that evenly distributes the interrupt request (IRQ) load across multiple CPUs for enhanced performance. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, the irqbalance service assigned interrupt requests (IRQs) also to isolated CPUs which were usually used for special dedicated purposes and were not under scheduler's control. Consequently, performance of tasks running on isolated CPUs could be reduced. With this update, irqbalance parses isolated CPUs from the kernel command line, and the performance of tasks running on them is thus no longer influenced. (BZ#1201552) Prior to this update, irqbalance did not honor banned CPU settings until the first rebalancing loop. As a consequence, when the irqbalance service was started or restarted, irqbalance incorrectly rebalanced IRQs, including the banned ones. This update ensures that IRQ affinity does not change shortly after irqbalance assigns it, thus fixing this bug. As a result, starting and restarting irqbalance no longer triggers an unintended rebalance operation. (BZ#1237356) Users of irqbalance are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
